awd_titl_txt: UNT Science and Mathematics Robert Noyce Scholarships
awd_abstract_narration: The University of North Texas (UNT) Science and Mathematics Robert Noyce Scholarships program is training 55 high school science and mathematics teacher candidates and supporting graduates in their early years of teaching in high need school districts, primarily in urban areas of North Texas.  The project is being supported by the strong infrastructure of the Teach North Texas program, UNT's replication of the successful UTeach program.  UNT is partnering with Fort Worth Independent School District and Denton Independent School District to provide high quality field experiences for teacher candidates and mentoring for beginning teachers.  Scholarships are being provided both for senior undergraduates who are majoring in Mathematics, Biology, or Chemistry and for post-baccalaureate students who majored in mathematics or science and are seeking secondary teaching certification.  In addition to completing mathematics or science majors, undergraduate students in this program are completing minors in Mathematics and Science Secondary Teaching and are being prepared for the licensure examinations from the Texas Examinations of Educators Standards.  Scholarship recipients are being provided with technology toolkits and are being trained to use these toolkits to effectively integrate technology into their classrooms.  Support during the induction years includes mentoring by a Master Teacher in the school, mentoring by a University Supervisor that visits the classroom and provides evaluative feedback, and an online mentoring forum that encourages the exchange of ideas on content-specific and pedagogical instructional strategies.  The project includes a longitudinal study of the impact of the Noyce Scholarship program on individuals supported under UNT's earlier Robert Noyce Scholarship award.

por.por_cntn:
The UNT Robert Noyce Science and Mathematics Scholarship Program aimed to increase the retention of high quality mathematics and science teachers in high need school districts by providing $10,000 scholarships to highly successful undergraduate teacher candidates. Recipients of the award were required to teach for two years in a high-needs school district, and this contributed to the high retention rate, especially for the first year.

Fifty-four secondary mathematics and science students were awarded the UNT Noyce Science and Mathematics scholarship. Those who graduated from the program showed strong mathematical or scientific knowledge (Avg. 3.33 GPA on a 4.0 scale with SD= 0.39), as well as pedagogical knowledge (Avg. 3.85 GPA with SD = 0.21). Of the 51 scholars who have taken the state certification exams, the average score for the content exam was 263 (SD = 12.5) and the average for the pedagogy and professional responsibilities exam was 270 (SD =11.67), which is significantly higher than the 240 passing score.

Because of the two-year requirement of teaching in a high-needs school district, the attrition rate after one year of teaching was only 2.5%. This is significantly less than reported by Ingersoll, Merrill, and May (2014) who described first year attrition rates of mathematics teachers as 14.5% and for science teachers as 18%. Eighty-eight percent of scholars choose to continue teaching in high need school district beyond two years. Godring, Taie, and Riddles (2014) reported that for affluent schools (less than 34% of students on free or reduced lunch), teachers maintained an 80% retention rate. Recipients of the UNT Robert Noyce Science and Mathematics Scholarship Program exceeded that rate and greatly surpassed the national retention rate for science and mathematics teachers in high-needs school districts. 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Colleen Eddy
